Here goes:

1. The vac doesnt hold but a little bit, and if your beard hair is any longer than setting 6 it can only get clogged.

2. That said, its nothing but a useless, noisey bulge that makes trimming a pain... not just under the nose and with the moustache as some have pointed out, but everywhere.

3. The settings, oh God the settings... the whole point of trimming your beard is to give it that clean, uniform look. If you're looking to get that "oh I haven't shaved in a few days aren't I chic look," this is your machine. If not, and you actually have a beard (and a thick one at that), the trimmer demands that you use a lot of force to attain an even cut; however, if you apply this force, the settings slide--and always down a notch.

4. The settings also react to the least bit of hand contact, so one has to be sure not to ever grab the machine too high up... but then even with this cautionary action, its likely to slip as described in tyrannous trimmer complaint #3.

5. Since you're looking over these reviews, trying to decide "is this for me and oh, is this for me?" I'd hasard a guess that you do indeed wish your face to look nice and the hair on it to appear well kept. If so, you probably wish to use the sclupting function to keep clear of Giraldo moustaches, pirate beards and the like. Unfortunately the sculpting function does no better than setting 2.

There you have it. Instead of plopping down the money for gadgetry that fails everytime, go for the simpler model, the smaller one, the one with the stategically placed setting switch, that one that makes your sink look like its just seen a balding rat climb out of the drain and shake all its loose hair hither and thither--God knows you're gonna have to clean it anyhow. I've used Norelcos for over 30 years. This latest version comes from China, with questionable implications as to quality and conditions of manufacture.
  Extremely light and quiet, it feels more like a woman's shaver. Therefore, it may not be suitable for men with heavy beards who are not accustomed to electric razors.
  Older Norelcos were solid, well made and came with solid cases; this model has no case at all, making careful handling essential. Considering this shaver's apparent fragility, if you ever drop it you'll need a new one. Norelco switches have always been erratic, so leave the switch turned on and unplug the shaver to turn it off.
  For the moment it does a good enough job, even without a closeness control. Its best feature is a full-sized trimmer, which works well.
  If today's lower quality standards for small appliances don't bother you, you may find this shaver perfectly acceptable but it is not built to last as long as its predecessors.
UPDATE (11/07) - Well, this fragile shaver is still going strong - of course, I've managed not to drop it! No complaints,  and the price has gone down a third since I bought it. Definitely the best shaver one can get at this price.
UPDATE (1/13) - Unfortunately I left the original shaver behind at an hotel and sorely missed it until I found a new, unused one on the internet. Norelco has apparently discontinued this model along with all their corded-only shavers, so if you can find one as I did, you're lucky!

On hindsight, maybe I should have used it. However, like other users, I've also encountered one serious design/manufacturing flaw with this product. Due to the way the on/off toggle switch is constructed and probably also the material the button is made of, I've had a few times when the switch just got stuck after the shaver was turned on. So you can imagine the panic when you try to turn the shaver off in the bathroom and it just refuses to. The first time it happened, no matter how many times I've tried, it just wouldn't turn off. I had to leave it running to exhaust its own battery power. Not a pretty nor quiet sight. This gadget is very loud when it's running. There was another time when I left it in the stand and it just decided to turn on by itself. Again, it stopped after exhausting itself. Thankfully, it happens less now for reasons I cannot explain. Sometimes, I just had to press a few more times to unstuck the off button. But, these weird incidents just knock a few notches off the overall experience.

For the money, this is a decent stand, nicely weighted and plated. Unfortunately I've found that the majority of my other brushes don't quite fit into the brush holder side of the stand.  If the manufacturer had increased the inner diameter of the brush holder by 1/8" this issue would have been solved.  It is possible in most cases to slide the brush into the stand where the bristles meet the handle but this leaves the brush unbalanced and easy to knock off the stand. This method also needs to be done with care as it increases the possibility of damaging the hairs or fibers on the brush.  Looks like I'm in the market for a replacement stand.  Sad that the brush gap isn't a bit wider as otherwise this stand would fit my needs nicely.  If you own multiple shaving brushes I recommend you measure the narrowest gap on the handle and make sure it doesn't exceed 1" in diameter before considering this purchase.

I got this shaver in early January of 2007.  For the first month or so that I had it, it worked decently.  The shave was relatively close and it did get most of the hair, but it did take a few passes over the skin, and a touch-up using the on-board trimmer to get the ones it missed.  I also found myself having the stretch the skin quite a bit to get a close enough shave.  However, it did offer an irritation-free shave (I have sensitive skin, thus why I stay away from blade razors).

Over the next few months, though, I noticed that the shave started to get more irritating: more 'pulling' instead of cutting (had always pulled a little, but got more frequent), takes more passes to cut what it once would, etc.  I changed the blades after 3 months (short period, yes, but I tried anyway).  It helped a little, but it still wasn't as good as it once was.  Then, I started to realize that the shaver wasn't holding as strong a charge as it once did.  It would come off the charger and be 'full power' for less than one shave, and would need to go back on the charger after 6 shaves (far less than the advertised two weeks).  A call to Norelco led nowhere, as they said it was 'expected' for the battery to wear down over time (4 months?).

I kept using the razor as I wasn't about to waste the $90 investment.  On a trip in late July, I had forgotten to pack the shaver, so I purchased a $10 Remington battery-operated foil razor at a local convenience store.  Sad to say, but from Day 1 that foil razor has outperformed the Norelco by leaps and bounds in all areas (closer shave, gets all areas better, less passes needed, etc.).  Also on a sad note, the Remington is kicking the bucket (a year later), and I am forced to go back to the Norelco for the time being while I look for an acceptable foil shaver as a replacement.

In short, this razor performed decently at first, but it seems as though compared to a $10 battery operated razor, this $70 shaver isn't a good value for the investment.

I hate this razor!  I used to have a 5814XL that finally died.  It was one of many Norelco razors that I have had for over 35 years.  When I needed to replace the 5814XL, I bought the 8825XL and after using it for 7 months, have come to despise its ability to provide a close shave.  Here are my comments on that deficiency as well as others:

1.  Even right out of the box, this shaver did not provide as close a shave as the old 5814XL.

2.  I suspect that in order to make it easy to clean, the cutting mechanism was modified to emphasize chopping the hairs up very finely.  In fact, I observe that the debris is indeed smaller than in the 5814XL.  Unfortunately it is so small that it falls out of the holes in the cutter heads thereby making a mess in the bathroom.  I think this may have compromised the ability of the 8825XL to shave close.

3.  The removal of the AC-DC converter from the shaver body to the cord is a mistake.

4.  The cord becomes unwieldy to store especially in the pouch.  The converter plug is so heavy, it falls out of any socket that is a bit loose.  This is especially a problem when shaving with the cord attached.

5.  The cord with its huge plug does not coil well.  The presence of the plug prevents the cord from being curled into any sort of small ball.  In fact, the stiffness and direction of the exit of the cord from the plug prevents the cord from being even closely wound around the plug.  This means that the cord and plug have effectively become twice as large.

6.  Presumably the point of removing the AC-DC converter to the plug was to reduce the size of the shaver body.  This was probably due to some styling guys wanting a "sexy" shape.  The shape is also a problem.  The shaver wants to tip over when stored on a shelf on its back.  Clearly the engineers noted this and added the two vestigial bumps on the back.  That this was an afterthought is clear since the bumps are so small - the result of ensuring that the plastic housing ejected easily from the mold during production.

7.  The adjustment wheel does not stay in the N position.  There is not enough friction to maintain that setting.  It constantly wants to move toward the S position.

8.  The desire to have the head on a hinge has also caused problems.  The detent that holds the hinge in the shaver body is not big enough.  Sometimes when I open the head to clean it, the spring action of the hinge and the smallness of the detent result in the head actually flipping off of the shaver. I've been dreaming about something like this for years.  I like to travel light and yet sometimes I would find myself wishing I could convert my small daily purse into a tote for larger items, a tablet computer or books - couldn't someone invent a convertible bag? Imagine my excitement when I finally found one!

Alas -- the idea (and the pictures advertising the item) is better than the actual product which is riddled with design flaws.  Too bad too, because this is such a neat idea!  With just a few tweeks in the design this item could be great but as it is it barely works at all.

CONS:
* This bag holds next to nothing. All I could manage to carry throughout all compartments was 3 credit cards, 4 bills, a few coins, a chapstick and a small hand sanitizer. All items were packed in EXTREMELY tight and it was hard to get anything in and out. Had they increased the dimensions of the wallet or compartments by just a tiny bit this bag would be much more useful.

* the small snap-closure pocket on the outside of the wallet section allows no room for any objects and bends the area on the interior wallet so that your credit cards bend and warp if you put anything in that pocket (there's only one spot for credit card slots -right on the wall of that compartment! They could have switched the credit card slots to the other side).  I did not over-stuff,  all I had in that pocket was the little chap-stick.  Certainly don't plan on carrying anything with any dimension in this pocket. At most you could fit a black plastic comb or a book-mark.  I don't know if it was because of the chap-stick or because of a miscalculation in sewing - but I couldn't get 1 row of the credit card slots to hold any cards at all- they seemed too narrow.

* The back pocket is lined for phones or sunglasses but the angle of the pouch and the velcro closure made me nervous about putting my touch screen phone in this pouch - it felt like it might pop open and the phone could only fit in without its little case.  (There's no other place in the purse which would accommodate a phone... so unless you have an older, tiny, light weight clam-shell phone or one you don't care about too much -- you're out of luck).  Also this pocket is only gusseted for dimension in two sides --- and flat on the bottom. What's the purpose of this?  Even less fits in and it would have been perfectly easy to make one 3rd "wall" to make the pouch bigger. Doing it this way only makes items smashed and difficult to get in or out.

* The WORST design flaw, aside from the small size of all the compartments is that getting the "tote" bag BACK into the compartment is very difficult and once unfolded, it never goes all the way flat again adding yet more ungainly bulk to the bag.  If you try to just stuff it back in, forget it.  You must fold the bag in exactly the way it came out... a feat that requires a little patience.  If you're bad at folding maps- just forget it.

* The two straps for carrying on your shoulder or around your waist  are very thin and located on either side of the main zippered area which makes it awkward to get into the wallet area.

* The bag is made of a stiff canvas material and is therefore not very light-weight.

PROS:

*When unfolded, the tote bag is much more useful and seems VERY sturdy and roomy.  -- You could use it just as a tote bag and never fold it back up with the wallet and sunglasses pouches still accessible on the exterior for trips to the beach I suppose - ...though there are more fashionable plain old totes for that purpose.

* Someone who carries only a card and some bills or coins and sunglasses to the farmers market or on garage sale trips might find this little bag quite useful.
For that reason, I marked it as a "3" instead of a 2 star - which it more deserves.
